column1: Father and daughter proceeded up the steps of the ice palace and came upon a banquet hall with three immensely long tables carved entirely out of ice, the frozen blocks filled with flowers and hauntingly lit so that the petals seemed suspended in space. Above the tables hovered six enormous crystal chandeliers lit with hundreds of candles, and the open archways at the far end of the palace perfectly framed the stupendous views. The sun had just dipped below the clouds, rendering the sky a deep violet that shimmered through the crystalline walls of the palace.

All this is rather moot, because lions don’t particularly enjoy the taste of ostrich. They much prefer antelope or zebra, served very rare.

Tera râ, te vai ra e piti na ofa'i pupuhi i ni'a i te avae tata'itahi, e na roto i te reira, e nehenehe ta'na e ou'a i ni'a i te hoê liona e te hoê noa tu'eraa popo. column1: The massive chiseled-and-hammered-copper double doors on the east side of the courtyard opened slowly as four men cloaked in hooded white and gold djellabas astride four white horses were silhouetted in the doorway. The horses cantered into the courtyard and came to a standstill by the central fountain, and the riders jumped off their horses and flung off their hoods, revealing themselves to be the two groomsmen, the best man, and the groom. The assembled guests applauded at the audacious entrance.

column1: “That’s where I was born! You know, right after my mom gave birth, my father bought a ninety-carat yellow diamond at auction from Christie’s and presented it to me at the hospital. It was an extremely rare diamond called the Golden Star, and he renamed it the Golden Martha. It made the front pages of all the newspapers. ‘Billionaire Buys Newborn Daughter Forty-Eight-Million-Dollar Diamond.’ Ever since then, I’ve been fodder for the papers, mainly in Asia. So I understand your problem.”

column13: "Nígbà tí mo lọ sí Miami ní oṣù Kejìlá tó kọjá, mo ṣàkíyèsí pé gbogbo olùkó iṣẹ́ ọnà ọlọ́rọ̀ bilionu ló ní oníṣẹ́-ọnà kan tí ó ń gbé ní ilé wọn. column23: "މިދިޔަ ޑިސެމްބަރު މަހު މަޔާމީއަށް ދިޔައިރު އަޅުގަނޑަށް ފާހަގަކުރެވުނީ ކޮންމެ ބިލިއަނަރު އާޓް ކަލެކްޓަރެއްގެ ގޭގައި އާޓިސްޓެއް އުޅޭކަން. އާޓިސްޓުން އެންމެން ވެސް މޮޔައެއް ފަދައިން ބޮސްދެމުން ދިޔައިރު، ހުރިހާ ދިމާލަކުން ވެސް އެމީހުންގެ ފަހަތުން އެމީހުންގެ ފަހަތުން ދިޔައިރު، އަހަރެން ހީކުރީ، އެމީހުންނަކީ ކިއުޓް ލިޓްލް ޕެޓްސް، އާޓް ޕެޓްސް ފަދަ ބައެކެވެ. އެހެންވީމާ، ކޮންމެ މަހަކު ވެސް އަޅުގަނޑަށް ތަފާތު އެއްޗެހި ލިބޭނެ. އެކުދިންނަށް ކާންދީ، ތިބޭނެ ތަނެއް ދީ، އޭގެ ބަދަލުގައި ހޮޓް އާޓިސްޓެއްގެ އަތުން ހިލޭ އާޓްވޯކެއް ލިބެއެވެ. އެންމެ ފަހުން އަހަރެންނާ އެކު މަޑުކުރި މީހާ އޭނާގެ ކުރެހުމަށް ނަފްރަތު ކުރި ނަމަވެސް ބައިމިލް ވަންދެން ފުރޮޅާލީމެވެ.

column1: “Not in the least. She was so very brave, your mother. I pretended not to know who she was—I sensed this was what she wanted—but after a few weeks she suddenly announced that she needed to go back to Vancouver and couldn’t finish her course of chemo and radiation. I pressed her to stay, seeing that the treatments were working, and that’s when she broke down and confessed to me that she needed to return because she had been away far too long from her child. My brother’s child. And that’s when I told her I had known all along who she was and would keep her secret safe. I convinced her to remain in Houston and to send for you.”

Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "Death in Venice" by Thomas Mann.

Here's my reasoning:

* The passage mentions "वेनिसमे" which means "in Venice", which is a key setting in the book "Death in Venice".
* The passage also mentions "एकटा बूढ़ आदमी" which means "an old man", which could refer to the protagonist of the book, Gustav von Aschenbach.

column21: Tsy misy ifandraisany amin'ny hoe lasa mpitondratena tany Venise izany. Momba ny lehilahy antitra iray izay variana amin'ny zazalahy kely tsara tarehy izany. Ankehitriny, mahazo alalana amin'ny tendron'ny asparagus fotsy ianao."
column22:
Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "The Picture of Dorian Gray" by Oscar Wilde.

column23: "ވެނިސްގައި ވިހެއުމަކަށް ހެދުމާ އެއްވެސް ގުޅުމެއް ނޯންނާނެ. އެއީ ރީތި ކުޑަ ފިރިހެން ކުއްޖަކާ މެދު މޮޔަވެފައި ހުރި މުސްކުޅި ފިރިހެނެއްގެ ވާހަކައެވެ. މިހާރު ކަލެއަށް ހުއްދަ ދެނީ ހުދު ކުލައިގެ އެސްޕަރަގަސް ޓިޕެއް."
column24: "title": "The Merchant of Venice","author": "William Shakespeare"
